conclusion: Two sliders A and B, each with mass m, are placed on an inclined plane with an angle θ = 37°.
Horizontal force F is applied to slider B.
Coefficient of friction μ = 0.5 and gravitational acceleration g.
Both sliders are just on the verge of not sliding upwards.
Slider A is positioned lower on the incline than slider B.
Slider B is connected to slider A by a rope.
A horizontal force F is applied to slider B to the right.

premise: Weight of slider A: mg (downward), Normal force: N₁ (perpendicular to incline), Tension force T in the rope (pulling up the incline), Friction force f₁ = μN₁ (opposing motion, pointing down the incline)
conclusion: For slider A to be on the verge of not sliding upwards, T - mg·sin θ - μN₁ = 0.

premise: Normal force calculation for slider A: N₁ = mg·cos θ
conclusion: Substituting N₁ into the force balance equation for slider A: T = mg·sin θ + μmg·cos θ

premise: Weight of slider B: mg (downward), Normal force: N₂ (perpendicular to incline), Tension force T in the rope (pulling down the incline), Friction force f₂ = μN₂ (opposing motion, pointing up the incline), Horizontal force F (to the right)
conclusion: Component of F parallel to the incline: F·cos θ

premise: Force balance parallel to the incline for slider B: F·cos θ - T - mg·sin θ + μN₂ = 0
conclusion: Normal force calculation for slider B: N₂ = mg·cos θ
